title: Can I still be successful if I had average grades? - Quora

response.answer_text: I teach science to 8th graders. Some have excellent grades, some average, some below. We do a variety of assignments, including several projects that involve STEM-type design and building. Students build rockets, egg drop devices, race tracks, paper origami structures, etc. Often, students who struggle in one area of assessment (ex. written exams) will excel in other areas (project-based learning). They just might have a brain better suited to spacial problems, or problem solving, or just plain creativity.  Moral is, having “average” grades does not necessarily preclude you from excelling at a profession. You may not have the grades to get into a top engineering school, but that doesn’t mean you’re completely cut off from a good STEM career. Not exactly science related, but my brother in law finished high school with average grades and dropped out of college (went back and finished eventually). He started working for a little start-up in OC CA stocking shelves in a little warehouse. The little company was called Paul Frank. He worked his way up and ended up a VP. Then he got an offer to work at another small clothing company just starting up, called RVCA. That went huge. He then ended up helping the son of the “Cabbage Patch Kids” inventor start his company, making animal-themed kids helmets called Raskullz. They hit it big and got product placed in Target and Walmart stores. By every measure he’s had a successful career, but his intelligence was never the kind that standardized tests measured well. Best of luck to you!

Justina Chua's answer to Can I still be successful if I had average grades? (http://Https://www.quora.com/Can-I-still-be-successful-if-I-had-average-grades/answer/Justina-Chua-2) was just excellent, I would only like to add that it is you who determines what does it mean to be succeful or not. It's your life, you're the one living it, and you're the only one to set expectations over it. There are a lot of fields in which your grades will not have any real matter for your success or not. Of course there are some in which you could be benefited for having good grades, but in most of the cases you can overcome it. What you need to do is to find out what your goals are, what is really important to you, and if the grades are really that important for those goals, maybe you should work really hard to get better in it, but if your goals require other abilities besides having good grades, that's what you should put your effort in.

It’s possible to be successful with average grades, but you need to understand that your grades are your first resume, and lack of success in the classroom makes it hard for you to get a good opportunity in other venues. Your detail in the question suggests you are interested in a STEM major. If so, you need to catch up. There are many millions of engineers in the world, and companies offer the best positions to applicants who have gone to good schools and earned good grades, because that is the primary evidence of success that will decide who gets hired. Finding projects and competitions is vital to establishing your name where it will be seen by companies. Seriously, you think college graduates want to be limited to Starbucks or Taco Bell?

If grades were to be a confirmation statement whether we will be successful or not, then today you wouldn't be using that iphone or using WINDOWS on your computer… Grades are the measurement of how good we can memorize and recall a certain subject. Don't let the society get to you Work from your own angle and you shall be successful

I was a low C average student in high school. I failed to complete college in my early twenties. I went back in my thirties, took seven years to graduate and finished with a high C average. At no point did I do any sort of significant extra curricular activities before going back to school of the types you mention. I did work in the service industry, though. And was good enough at that to be various kinds of management. I am currently, by most definitions of successful, successful. I make enough money to be in the 20%. I am married. I have one daughter with a master's degree and another that is about half way through her bachelor's. I also helped my wife get her nursing degree. So yes, average students can be successful.

Graduated top 49% of my class. Dropped out of college. Now a professional programmer. I am not dumb, or unmotivated. I have read more books this year than most college students will read in their entire college experience. I don’t require approval from a professor. I don’t like being spoon fed information. I've been a part of a few start ups. I currently work for an awesome company. Get your degree from an accredited state college. You don't sound like a doctor or Phd candidate. Those fields rely on good grades and a certain academic flare. Now, this is a blanket statement for every slacker in the history of ever, there are exceptions. Blue collar - trade school. Art student - art school. Programmer - boot camp?

Yes, if you can push yourself. The truth is that most school grading system is not sufficient to confer you a success or failure in the real, unforgiving business world. Their is that thing called being street wise, having soft-skills, always being a person of the people, good interpersonal attribute all this might not necessarily give you straight As in school but sure you need them to be successful. Be bold, know your weaknesses, accept them and deal with them and never see yourself as lacking the requisite to be successful. All the best!!

Yes, definitely, you can succeed! If the dropouts can succeed, why not an average high school student? Don’t let grades limit you. Examples: 23 Famous Dropouts Who Turned Out Just Fine Top 10 College Dropouts - TIME Helpful Links: How To Be Successful In Life: 13 Tips From The World’s Most Successful People 7 Scientifically Proven Ways to Achieve Better Success in Life How to be Successful? [23 Keys to Success in Life] How To Become Wildly Successful At Anything 30 Things You Need To Know To Be Successful In Life Goodluck!

Eventually, you must become good at something. I was so average in high school that I failed a few classes and an A- in just one class was the best I could do. I knew I wasn’t stupid. So, against my counselor’s expectations, I went to college. There I finally bloomed and discovered my passion. I excelled in classes I liked and was average in those I didn’t. If you yearn to be successful, be patient until you find where your hot button is.

I think so- but going to a good university and hence completing more difficult projects as a scientist could help!... I don't know what country your from, but in mine as long as you get the grades you can probably get into uni to study whatever you want- apart from medicine, and personally I know very few people who ever applied to stem craft fairs! But even more important that your university could be finding good placements/ internships- and for that you just need perseverance (etc).
Yes. Success depends more on hard work, ability, personality, connections, luck and other intangibles that are only partially measured by grades.

Everyone has some qualities and it is never related to your grades or interests. Sometimes you cannot find that quality within you and it comes out on its own time. But sometimes you know your interest and you work for it and consequently Almighty bless you with success. Believe on your deeds and fate both & keep working, Keep running, Keep Smiling on the harsh road of life :)

I consider myself successful. I graduated college. I got a toehold in the veterinary furld with an awesome veterinarian who is going to actually pay for my continued education in the field. And my highest grade was a B. I am average. But successful.
watching it carefully. success doesn't matter with your grades. always depend how much you paid and how long you take on one thing.
I believe you can be successful. You will have to apply yourself, work hard, have a plan, have preservation.
Of course it all depends on how determined and disciplined you are

Ha ha - I LOVE this question. Clearly you haven’t read that C and B students usually end up having wonderful lives and are successful be almost every measure. There are lots of articles about this odd result. Here is one: 10 Reasons Why C Students Are More Successful After Graduation
It matters a bit but don’t worry and try to improve your college grades because when you will go for job interview they will look at your college grades.
